Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of Hydrologic Processes on In Situ Stress Transients
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how water moves and is stored within the landscape is among the most pervasive themes of hydrological research, but important aspects of the water cycle remain poorly known. The proposed research project will address current limitations in characterizing the water cycle and is motivated by two related hypotheses: 1. Hydrologically important changes in water content are sufficient to cause measurable changes in the in situ state of stress. 2. Transient changes of in situ stress can be used to estimate hydrologic fluxes and changes in storage over multiple scales.
This investigation will develop conceptual and numerical methods for analyzing hydrologic processes associated with changes of in situ stress as well as instruments and field techniques for measuring these changes. New field instrumentation will be developed to measure total and effective stress changes with a target resolution of 1 Pa. A proof-of-concept field test near Clemson, SC will compare high resolution stress measurements to transient changes in water content and other processes. A more rigorous field test will take place in Kansas, where the method will be used to estimate changes in mass resulting from evapotranspiration and other effects in a riparian zone along the Arkansas River. Theoretical analyses of poroelasticity in the vadose and saturated zones will be used to evaluate how stresses are affected by changes in water content, as well as a variety of other potentially competing effects including barometric pressure change, subsurface geology, earth tides, ground water extraction, regional horizontal flows, surface impoundments, traffic, wind, temperature, etc.
New field approaches are catalysts for discovery in hydrologic sciences, and the intellectual merit of the proposed investigation is that it has the potential to be such a catalyst for discovery. The investigation will provide the scientific basis for new field techniques, theoretical analyses and instrumentation that will advance the ability to characterize key aspects of the hydrological cycle (ET, change in soil moisture, recharge, stormflow, etc.) over scales from less than 1 m to greater than 100 m. The techniques developed for this project will have broad impacts by providing multi-scale data that can be used to improve: validation and calibration of remote sensing instruments and algorithms; estimates of melting or accumulation of snow pack or glaciers; assessment of rates of erosion or sediment deposition; reduction of noise and resolution of tectonic strain; assessment of rates of carbon storage; methods for scheduling irrigation; understanding mass changes resulting from forest fires, and related.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the movement and storage of water at shallow depths is an overarching goal of the hydrologic sciences, and this project was motivated by the possibility of using a new signal to help meet this goal.  Changes in water content cause soil to deform and we evaluated the possibility of using this deformation signal to monitor hydrologic processes. 

A New Instrument   The first step in the research involved developing an instrument that could measure small deformations.  We wanted to create an instrument that was easy to install, robust to operate, and relatively inexpensive.  We call the device we developed a DELTA extensometer (DEL-X for short).  It consists of two cylindrical anchors separated by a connecting rod that extends from the bottom to the top anchor (Figure 1).  A key feature of the design is that the high-resolution, sensitive transducer used to measure vertical displacement is lowered in place after the anchors and rod are installed to avoid damaging the sensor.  All the DEL-X instruments installed using the current design (approximately 15) have functioned properly.  Two of them have been operational for more than 5 years, although this has required replacing electronic components from time to time. 

DEL-X Performance   The DEL-X extensometer has remarkable sensitivity.  The average noise over 5 minutes is less than 5 nanometers.  The elastic properties of soil allow these small displacements to be translated into small changes in load, much like the spring in a kitchen scale is used to weigh food.  In this case, though, the extensometer makes high resolution measurements of the change in weight of the overlying material averaged over a radial distance that is roughly twice its depth.  This potentially provides a method for averaging changes in soil water content over 100s of m2 or more.   

Application   We installed DEL-X instruments at our field site in Clemson, SC, and in playas in north Texas and in a research cornfield in Nebraska (Figure 2).  We found that vertical deformation in shallow soils is caused by three main processes (Figure 3):  1.) changes in elastic load above the instrument; 2.) changes in the pore pressure in the vicinity of the instrument;  3.) changes in temperature in the vicinity of the instrument. 

We were particularly interested in the changes in elastic load, but we found that the changes in pore pressure were important in some cases.   Ranfall has a particularly striking effect, causing compression in the underlying soil as the water content increases above it (Figure 4).  Extension occurs during ET  between rainfall (Figure 4).   The effect of rainfall can be sharpened by accounting for fluctuations in barometric pressure (Figure 4).  There were many dozen rainfalls during our record and we found that the vertical displacement consistently correlated with the rainfall amount (Figure 5).  Estimates of the net change in water volume per unit area made using the calibration factor from rainfall were similar to independent estimates of evapotranspiration.   We developed capabilities to simulate small strains in the vadose and saturated zones using numerical and analytical solutions to poroelastic equations, and this provides an important theoretical foundation for interpreting strain signals  (Figure 6). 

Teaching and learning    The project has contributed training and professional development to three graduate students, a post doc, and 10 undergraduate students in Geology and six in Mechanical Engineering.  A researcher in soil physics from China spent a sabbatical year in our lab to learn about the technique.  We collaborated with colleagues in Texas and Nebraska to demonstrate the DEL-X extensometer at their research sites (Figure 2).  Project personnel developed strong, and productive ties with industry, and one of the graduate students was subsequently hired by the Meter Group, a leading manufacturer of hydrologic equipment. 

Broader scientific community    Small deformation caused by hydrologic processes is of interest beyond the hydrologic community, and as part of this project we engaged with the geodesy and climate change mitigation communities.  Geodetic data are affected by small movements of GPS base stations caused by deformation in soil, and our findings can be used to account for these movements.  Carbon storage in the subsurface is a leading technology for mitigating the buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere, and characterizing pressure distribution during injection is a key monitoring strategy to identify CO2 leaks.  We proposed to extend the DEL-X technology with methods we learned about from out colleagues in geodesy in order to monitor small deformations from presurized CO2.  This idea has evolved into a follow-on investigation that one day could help improve the security of the geologic carbon storage process.    

Summary:  This project showed that minute deformations at shallow depths caused by natural or man-made processes could be measured with a simple instrument and interpreted using conceptual and quantitative analyses.  This has created a new perspective for monitoring the movement and storage of water in the hydrologic system.
